text:
Agency 2: "Re: 'All congressional correspondence logs from January 1, 2018 to the present.' What does the requestor mean by 'correspondence?' What does the requestor mean by 'log?' What does the requestor mean by 'all?'"

(The agency used to routinely release these.)
author: gregorykorte

text:
It's not even 9:30 a.m., and I have three mind-blowing #FOIA responses:

Agency 1: We're not going to give you the records, but we're also not going to give you a denial. So go ahead and sue us if you want.

text: So now, as @AndyGrewal points out, it requires a joint resolution -- which can be vetoed by the president.
author: gregorykorte

text: No. Back in the day Congress concocted these mechanisms that would let the president take an action unless they affirmatively voted to overturn it by simple majority vote. But in 1983, the Supreme Court ruled in INS v. Chadha that such a "legislative veto" was unconstitutional.
author: gregorykorte

text: Best Dylan song ever.
author: gregorykorte

text: True. But I think once Congress (or the courts) give power to the president, it's almost impossible to rein in absent a supermajority that's unlikely in a politically polarized Congress. Whether Congress intended it this way or not, we're stuck with it.
author: gregorykorte

text: Here's a Solicitor General's opinion from 1934: "Since the method of approval is strictly prescribed, the method of disapproval is equally so and should be observed."
author: gregorykorte

text:
When Congress passed the National Emergencies Act in 1976, the Supreme Court hadn't yet struck down the "legislative veto." So if the process worked the way Congress envisioned it back then, the Senate vote today would have been the last word.

But it's not.
author: gregorykorte

text: Beto O'Rourke has positioned himself as a self-made grassroots candidate of small donations. But I still remember the day @fschouten and I, tracking down different paper trails on campaign contributions in 2012, ended up at the same P.O. Box owned by O'Rourke's father-in-law.
author: gregorykorte

text: But he has to use it retroactively every once in a while if it's going to work as a prospective inducement.

text: President Trump has the votes to sustain a veto on this, as he likely does with the wall emergency. But the fact that Congress is even exercising some of these long-dormant mechanisms is remarkable in itself.
author: gregorykorte

text: It looks like the action was taken by the Acting FAA Administrator by his authority under 49 U.S. Code § 46105(c), which allows him to "issue orders immediately to meet the emergency, with or without notice."
author: gregorykorte

text: Yes, the executive branch reports to the President. That doesn't mean the President can order any action unless he has constitutional or statutory authority to do so. If there is an executive order, it will have that citation. But I suspect this was an agency-level action.
author: gregorykorte

text: I suspect this one might be more phone than pen.

text: I'm sure the FAA can, and I take it that's what's happening here. So it sounds like perhaps Trump is just using Trumpian language to say he's doing something, when it's really his administration. (A nuanced distinction, but important in the context of unitary executive.)
author: gregorykorte

text: Can he do this? On what legal authority? I'd like to see the order.

text: I agree. But it also seems to me that Congress is considering a law that shouldn’t be necessary if politicians would just foster a greater respect for the First Anendment.
author: gregorykorte

text: Also: How will Congress define “journalist?” Are all journalists necessarily engaged in interstate commerce, or will only national reporters be covered? Will menacing, threats and extortion be covered, or only physical violence?
author: gregorykorte

text: I’m not sure how I feel about this. While I’m very concerned about growing threats of violence against journalists, I’ve also long thought that journalists deserve no greater or lesser legal protections than anyone else.
author: gregorykorte

text: This is a central thesis of @DavidPriess's book "How to Get Rid of a President." It may not be the instant gratification that some want, but the most democratic way to remove a president is at the ballot box.
